subject: Home & DIY
title: Roman Public Bathhouses
description: A micro-lesson that makes Roman Public Bathhouses usable.

hook.text: By 300 AD, Rome had over 900 public bathhouses. Bathing wasn't just hygieneâ€”it was the Roman version of social media.

buildup.text: Bathhouses had hot rooms (caldarium), warm rooms (tepidarium), and cold plunges (frigidarium). Bathers used all three.

discovery.text: The hypocaust heated floors from below: slaves burned wood in furnaces, and hot air flowed under raised tile floors.

twist.text: Bathhouses were freeâ€”state subsidized. Even the poorest bathed daily, a standard Europe wouldn't see for 1,500 years.

climax.text: After Rome fell, Christianity linked public bathing with sin. Europe entered centuries of terrible hygiene.

punchline.text: Rome bathed daily. Medieval Europe bathed yearly.

quiz.question: How did Roman hypocaust systems heat bathhouse floors?
options: Hot air from wood furnaces circulated under raised tile floors
Steam was piped from natural hot springs nearby
Heated stones were placed beneath the floor tiles
